choices.text: Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout
Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout
Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-
Increased excretion of H+

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 mEq/L, paco2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout

 

ABG shows pH 7.3 (acidosis) → Metabolic (HCO3- = 10)

 

Expected pCO2 = HCO3 +15 = 25 is < actual pCO2 (30) suggesting there is excess CO2 than expected. Hypoventilation leads to CO2 accumulation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hyperventilation leads to excess CO2 washout: And would have reduced the pCO2 levels than the expected values.

 

Option C. Increased absorption of HCO3: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option D. Increased H+ excretion: Will lead to metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, compare the actual respiratory response (PaCO2) with what is theoretically expected. Inadequate reduction in PaCO2, or relative hypoventilation, suggests partial compensation, highlighting a need for further intervention to correct the underlying acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shock

 

Apoplexy refers to acute neurologic impairment due to a vascular compromise, usually hemorrhage, resulting in headache, visual disturbance and hormonal dysfunction due to infarction of pituitary gland.

 

Loss of glucocorticoids results in shock.

 

MRI is used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management:

 

  • If shock is present: IV glucocorticoids + IV fluids to maintain hemodynamic stability
  • If worsening neurologic symptoms (VA, GCS): Surgical decompression

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension: Typically, hypertension is not a direct consequence of pituitary apoplexy. Instead, hypotension and shock are more common due to adrenal insufficiency.

 

Option C. Unconsciousness: While not the most direct symptom, unconsciousness can occur if the apoplexy leads to significant increase in intracranial pressure or severe complications, but it's not as characteristic as shock.

 

Option D. Fatigue: Although patients may experience fatigue due to hormonal imbalances, it's not a primary or immediate concern in the acute setting of pituitary apoplexy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shock is a critical and life-threatening manifestation of pituitary apoplexy that arises from acute adrenal insufficiency. Immediate recognition and treatment with IV glucocorticoids and fluids are essential to stabilize the patient and prevent further complications. This condition is diagnosed via imaging, typically an MRI, and may require surgical intervention depending on the severity and the presence of neurological symptoms.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Pituitary tumor syndromes/Page no 2897

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies has the least or no established association with obesity? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastric pyloric cancer

 

Gastric pyloric cancer is not associated with obesity. While obesity is linked to many gastrointestinal cancers, the association with gastric cancer is site-specific. 

 

Obesity has been linked to gastric cardia (upper stomach) cancers but not to pyloric (lower stomach) cancers. The relationship between obesity and gastric cancer depends on the anatomical location within the stomach. Gastric cardia cancers, which occur in the upper portion of the stomach near the gastroesophageal junction, show association with obesity, whereas pyloric cancers do not demonstrate this relationship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningioma: This is associated with obesity. Meningioma is one of the few brain tumors that has been linked to obesity. Increased BMI has been identified as a risk factor for developing meningiomas.

 

Option B. Pancreatic cancer: This is strongly associated with obesity. Pancreatic cancer is part of the hepatobiliary-pancreatic system cancers that have been linked to obesity and increased BMI. Obesity is considered a significant risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: This is associated with obesity. Studies have linked multiple myeloma and some leukemias to obesity and increased BMI. The association between obesity and hematological malignancies, particularly multiple myeloma, has been established in epidemiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric pyloric cancer is not associated with obesity, unlike gastric cardia cancer which shows positive association with increased BMI.

 

Note – 

 

  • Best answer would be Premenopausal breast cancer (in females) or prostate cancer (in males) – not related to obesity.
  • Ovarian cancer and postmenopausal breast cancer are associated with obesity

questions.text: A young male presents with vesicular lesions on the external genitalia. Biopsy shows Tzanck cells. What would be the appropriate treatment for this patient? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

The clinical presentation of vesicular lesions on external genitalia combined with the finding of Tzanck cells on biopsy is pathognomonic for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Tzanck cells are multinucleated giant cells that are characteristic of herpes virus infections.

 

Acyclovir is the first-line antiviral treatment for HSV infections, including genital herpes. It works by inhibiting viral DNA polymerase, thereby preventing viral replication. Valacyclovir, the prodrug of acyclovir, is also an appropriate alternative with better bioavailability and fewer gastrointestinal side effects, though acyclovir remains more cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used primarily for bacterial infections such as gonorrhea, not viral infections like HSV. It would be ineffective against herpes simplex virus.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used for bacterial infections, particularly atypical bacteria and some sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia. It has no activity against herpes simplex virus.

 

Option D. Penicillin: This is a beta-lactam antibiotic effective against certain bacterial infections, particularly syphilis among sexually transmitted infections. It has no antiviral activity and would be ineffective against HSV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tzanck cells in vesicular genital lesions indicate herpes simplex virus infection, which requires antiviral treatment with acyclovir.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) based on the triad of:

 

  • Hematuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • History of bloody diarrhea

 

E. coli O157:H7, also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) or Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), is the most common causative organism of HUS, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shigella flexneri

 

  • Incorrect because while it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is more commonly associated with reactive arthritis rather than HUS.
  • Does not typically cause the combination of hematuria and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Salmonella enteritis

 

  • Incorrect as it is primarily associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • Not typically associated with HUS.

 

Option D. Aeromonas

 

  • Incorrect as it typically causes simple diarrhea without the complications of HUS.
  • Does not produce Shiga toxin, which is responsible for HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: What type of deposition is typically observed in patients with dialysis-related amyloidosis? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta 2 microglobulin

 

Explanation:

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA) occurs in patients who have been on long-term hemodialysis.

 

The primary protein responsible for amyloid deposits in DRA is beta 2 microglobulin. This protein tends to accumulate in patients undergoing chronic hemodialysis because it is not efficiently removed by dialysis filters.

 

The deposition of beta 2 microglobulin can lead to various musculoskeletal complications, including:

 

  • Arthritis: Particularly common in the shoulder joint, referred to as "shoulder arthropathy."
  • Tenosynovitis: Inflammation of the tendon sheath.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome: Compression of the median nerve in the wrist, leading to pain, numbness, and weakness in the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid beta: This type of amyloid is primarily associated with Alzheimer's disease and is not related to dialysis.

 

Option B. Beta 1 macroglobulin: This is not related to dialysis-related amyloidosis.

 

Option D. Transthyretin: This protein can cause amyloidosis but is associated with other forms, such as senile systemic amyloidosis (wild-type transthyretin) and familial transthyretin amyloidosis (mutated transthyretin), which typically affect the heart and nervous system rather than causing musculoskeletal issues.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Dialysis-related amyloidosis is primarily caused by the accumulation of beta 2 microglobulin, leading to musculoskeletal complications such as arthritis, tenosynovitis, and carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: The most virulent form of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is seen in which type of MEN syndrome.? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MEN-2B

 

Explanation:

 

MEN-2B is associated with the most virulent and aggressive form of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MEN-2B is specifically associated with codon 918 mutations that lead to the most aggressive form of MTC, requiring thyroidectomy at a very early age (<1 year). This syndrome presents with mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and the earliest and most aggressive presentation of MTC among all the MEN syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MEN-1: This is incorrect. MEN-1 (Wermer syndrome) is not typically associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma. MEN-1 is characterized by primary hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, not MTC.

 

Option B. MEN-2A: This is incorrect. While MEN-2A (Sipple syndrome) does include medullary thyroid carcinoma as a component (~90% of cases), it is not the most virulent form. The MEN-2B variant has a more aggressive clinical course with earlier onset and more rapid progression.

 

Option D. FMTC: This is incorrect. Familial Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (FMTC) is a variant of MEN-2A but is not associated with the most aggressive form of MTC. FMTC typically has a less aggressive presentation than MTC in MEN-2B and may present with isolated MTC without other syndrome components.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

MEN-2B is characterized by the most aggressive form of medullary thyroid carcinoma, often presenting very early in life, with codon 918 mutations carrying the highest risk and requiring prophylactic thyroidectomy before 1 year of age.

choices.text: Normal leukocyte counts

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Gaisböck syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotension

 

Gaisböck syndrome, also known as stress polycythemia or stress erythrocytosis, is characterized by a chronic relative increase in red blood cell count due to reduced plasma volume, not an actual increase in RBC production. Patients typically exhibit the following features:

 

  • Hypertension, not hypotension
  • Relative erythrocytosis
  • Normal leukocyte counts
  • Obesity

 

Note – DD - Polycythemia: Patients with polycythemia typically present with splenomegaly, Patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not exhibit splenomegaly.

 

Key Features of Gaisböck Syndrome:

 

  • Relative Erythrocytosis: An apparent increase in RBC count due to decreased plasma volume.
  • Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is common in these patients.
  • Normal Leukocyte Counts: There is no increase in white blood cells.
  • Obesity: Many patients with Gaisböck syndrome are obese.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythrocytosis: Erythrocytosis is a hallmark of Gaisböck syndrome due to reduced plasma volume.

 

Option C. Normal leukocyte counts: Patients with Gaisböck syndrome typically have normal leukocyte counts.

 

Option D. Obesity: Obesity is commonly associated with Gaisböck syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaisböck syndrome is characterized by relative erythrocytosis, hypertension, normal leukocyte counts, and obesity. Hypotension & splenomegaly is not a feature of this syndrome.

choices.text: Cover with hot damp sheets
Cover with cool damp sheets

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration but radial pulse was present. His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following should be given as first aid in this case? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cover with cool damp sheets

 

The man is experiencing classic heat stroke, indicated by high body temperature and collapse. The first aid should involve cooling measures, such as covering with cool damp sheets, to lower body temperature rapidly and prevent organ damage.

 

There are two main types of cooling methods for managing heat-related illnesses:

 

  1. Passive Cooling: This involves placing the patient in a shaded area or a cool environment without any additional measures. It relies on the natural cooling effect of the environment.
  2. Active Cooling: This method involves more direct and proactive cooling techniques and can be further divided into:
    • Active External Cooling: Applying cool, damp sheets, ice water, or using ice water baths to reduce body temperature.
    • Active Internal Cooling: Infusing cold saline solutions, such as cold dextrose in normal saline (DNS) or cold Ringer's lactate (RL), chilled to around 15°C.

 

For immediate treatment, both passive and active cooling methods should be utilized. Active cooling, especially using cold and damp sheets, is commonly employed for effective temperature reduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inject epinephrine immediately: Not indicated for heat stroke; used for anaphylaxis.

 

Option B. Cover with hot damp sheets: Would worsen the condition by increasing body temperature.

 

Option D. Start CPR: Not necessary as the patient has a radial pulse and is not in cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cooling measures, like covering with cool damp sheets, are crucial in the first aid for heat stroke.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady noticed a mass in the front of her neck. Otherwise, she has no symptoms. On examination, she had a solitary thyroid nodule. Which of the following is the appropriate initial investigation in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid function testing

 

The first step in evaluating a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function. This is done through thyroid function tests, which typically include measuring levels of TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone), T3 (triiodothyronine), and T4 (thyroxine). These tests help determine if the nodule is causing any hormonal imbalances, such as hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) or hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT scan: It may be used later in the evaluation to assess the size and extent of the nodule, but it is not the initial investigation.

 

Option C. I-123 scan: It helps identify areas of increased or decreased activity, which can be helpful in distinguishing between benign and malignant nodules. However, it is not the initial investigation.

 

Option D. I-131 scan: It is primarily used for the treatment of hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer, not for the initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation for a solitary thyroid nodule is thyroid function testing (TSH, T3, and T4).

choices.text: Subintimal lipid infiltration with smooth muscle necrosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with tearing pain in the chest that intensely radiated to his back. He had non-specific ECG changes and his Trop I was negative. During the course of his evaluation he passed away. Biopsy of the aorta obtained during autopsy is shown. What is the likely mechanism behind his disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Connective tissue weakness

 

The clinical presentation (tearing chest pain radiating to the back) and the absence of ECG changes or elevated troponin suggest aortic dissection. The autopsy finding of a split intima further confirms this diagnosis.

 

Aortic dissection occurs when there is a tear in the inner layer (intima) of the aorta, allowing blood to flow between the layers of the aortic wall. The primary underlying cause of aortic dissection is connective tissue weakness in the aortic wall. This weakness can be due to inherited conditions (like Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) or other factors like hypertension and aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrinoid necrosis: This is seen in vasculitis and malignant hypertension, but it is not the primary mechanism behind aortic dissection.

 

Option B. Subintimal lipid infiltration with smooth muscle necrosis: This is characteristic of atherosclerosis, which can lead to aneurysms but is not the typical cause of aortic dissection.

 

Option C. Immune complex vasculitis: Vasculitis can weaken the aortic wall, but it is a less common cause of aortic dissection compared to connective tissue weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely mechanism behind aortic dissection is connective tissue weakness in the aortic wall.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

The image shows dilated medium-sized bronchi, a characteristic feature of bronchiectasis. The signet ring appearance and tram track sign on imaging further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary tuberculosis: Would show cavitary lesions or miliary nodules.

 

Option B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: Shows hyperinflation and flattened diaphragms.

 

Option C. Bronchial asthma: Typically shows normal imaging or hyperinflation during an acute attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis is diagnosed by the presence of dilated bronchi and characteristic imaging signs.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs the ability of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to stimulate muscle contractions, leading to decreased synaptic transmission. The disease is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly worsening with activity and improving with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased myosin: This option is not related to myasthenia gravis, which primarily affects the neurotransmitter receptors, not the muscle fiber proteins like myosin.

 

Option B. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: While decreased acetylcholine release can affect neuromuscular function, in myasthenia gravis, the principal issue is the reduced effectiveness of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction due to antibody-mediated receptor damage, not a reduction in its release. Occurs with pre-synaptic blockers like bungarotoxin of krait causing reduced release of Ach rendering neostigmine ineffective.

 

Option C. Absence of troponin C: This is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis. Troponin C is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not neurotransmitter release or receptor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by Ab to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Hence, treated with steroids and immunomodulators.

choices.text: Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy
Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber's syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

 

LMN Facial palsy occurs in pontine/infra-pontine syndromes.

 

WEBER'S SYNDROME

 

Infarction - Ipsilateral subthalamus and medial thalamus injury with ipsilateral cerebral peduncle and mid- brain lesions.

 

Involvement:

 

  • Third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia (localized to the cerebral peduncle).
  • Subthalamic nucleus - Contralateral hemiballismus
  • Occlusion of the artery of Percheron - Paresis of upward gaze and drowsiness
  • If bilateral proximal PCA occlusion - coma, unreactive pupils, bilateral pyramidal signs, and decerebrate rigidity.

 

Note: A Third nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia - Claude's syndrome. The ataxia indicates involvement of the red nucleus or dentato-rubro-thalamic tract.

 

  • Weber, claude, benedict are medial brainstem syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral hemiplegia: Correct for Weber's syndrome, as it involves the cerebral peduncle, affecting motor pathways that result in weakness on the opposite side of the body.

 

Option B. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Also correct, reflecting the typical involvement of the third cranial nerve, which controls eye movements, eyelid opening, pupil constriction, and most of the eye's focusing muscles.

 

Option C. Contralateral Parkinsonism: While not classically described as a symptom of Weber’s syndrome, it could theoretically relate to potential involvement of nearby structures influencing motor function. However, it is less specific and not as classic a presentation as contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weber’s syndrome involves ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia due to midbrain lesions, and does not typically include ipsilateral facial paralysis, which is associated with pontine lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely to occur in short bowel syndrome? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is most likely to occur in short bowel syndrome since B12 absorption occurs exclusively in the terminal ileum. When portions of the small intestine are surgically removed or functionally impaired, B12 absorption is significantly compromised. Malnutrition due to inadequate caloric intake is exceedingly rare with short bowel syndrome, but specific micronutrient deficiencies can develop. B12 deficiency may be secondary to impaired absorption or diminished oral intake, resulting in megaloblastic anemia and neurologic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biotin: Biotin is absorbed throughout the small intestine and can also be synthesized by intestinal bacteria. Therefore, biotin deficiency is less common in short bowel syndrome compared to B12 deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine is primarily absorbed in the jejunum. While thiamine deficiency can occur in malabsorptive states, it's less specific to short bowel syndrome than B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is both absorbed in the small intestine and synthesized by colonic bacteria. Unless there is extensive small bowel and colonic resection, vitamin K deficiency is less common than B12 deficiency in short bowel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin B12 absorption occurs exclusively in the terminal ileum, making its deficiency a hallmark of short bowel syndrome, especially when the terminal ileum is resected or diseased.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

 

The clinical presentation suggests anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, irritability, and urinary retention. Datura, commonly known as jimsonweed or thorn apple, contains tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Anticholinergic toxicity manifests with:

 

  • Central nervous system effects: confusion, hallucinations, irritability
  • Peripheral effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia, hyperthermia

 

The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic toxicity is a cholinergic drug like physostigmine, which increases the levels of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow oleander; Physostigmine: Yellow oleander poisoning involves cardiac glycosides similar to digoxin, which can cause bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The antidote for oleander poisoning is Digibind, not physostigmine.

 

Option B. Datura; Digibind: While datura poisoning is correctly identified here, Digibind is the antidote for digoxin or digitalis toxicity, not anticholinergic toxicity caused by datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander; Digibind: This option correctly pairs yellow oleander poisoning with its antidote, Digibind. However, the clinical presentation does not fit yellow oleander poisoning, which typically involves bradycardia and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than confusion and urinary retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: A 41-year-old construction worker in Uttar Pradesh collapsed at the construction site in the afternoon of a summer day. Which of the following is least likely to be seen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sweating

 

The scenario describes a case of classic heat stroke, which is a medical emergency characterized by an elevated core body temperature (often above 104°F or 40°C) and central nervous system dysfunction due to exposure to high environmental temperatures.

 

Sweating is typically absent in classic heat stroke. This is because the body’s thermoregulatory mechanisms fail, and the skin becomes hot and dry. In contrast, in exertional heat stroke (which occurs during intense physical activity), sweating may still be present.

 

Other Options:

 

In classic heat stroke, particularly due to prolonged exposure to high environmental temperatures:

 

Option A. Temperature of 105°F: It is common to have very high body temperatures in heat stroke.

 

Option C. Hypotension: Can occur due to dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Tachypnea: Increased respiratory rate is a compensatory mechanism to help cool the body and deal with metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic heat stroke, typically caused by high environmental temperatures, the patient often presents with high body temperature, hypotension, and tachypnea, but lacks sweating. This distinguishes it from exertional heat stroke, where sweating might still be present.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas report is as follows: pH 7.2, pCO2 81mm Hg, and HCO3 40 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory acidosis

 

The arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows a pH of 7.2, which indicates acidosis (normal pH: 7.35-7.45). The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is elevated at 81 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), indicating that the acidosis is due to a respiratory cause, as CO2 retention leads to respiratory acidosis.

 

The bicarbonate (HCO3) level is elevated at 40 mEq/L (normal range: 22-28 mEq/L). This elevation suggests that the kidneys are compensating for the respiratory acidosis by retaining bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions, indicating a chronic component to the respiratory acidosis.

 

In summary, the primary disturbance is respiratory acidosis, evidenced by the elevated pCO2, and the elevated bicarbonate suggests a compensatory response by the kidneys, characteristic of chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and low pCO2, which is the opposite of the findings in this ABG report.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Metabolic acidosis would present with a low pH and a low bicarbonate level. However, in this case, the bicarbonate is elevated, not decreased, indicating the primary issue is not metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by a high pH and elevated bicarbonate, but without the accompanying high pCO2. The presence of high pCO2 and low pH indicates the primary disturbance is respiratory, not metabolic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blood gas report showing low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory elevated bicarbonate indicates respiratory acidosis, often with a chronic component if the bicarbonate is significantly elevated.

questions.text: The most common cause of Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) is the rapid correction of? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyponatremia.

 

Explanation:

 

Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), is most commonly caused by rapid correction of hyponatremia. Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) disrupts the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing immune mediators to enter and contribute to demyelination. The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons, where the delay in reaccumulation of osmotic osmolytes is particularly pronounced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause various neurological symptoms including weakness and paralysis, it is not the primary cause of CPM. Neurological manifestations of hypokalemia differ from the characteristic demyelinating pattern seen in CPM.

 

Option B. Hypomagnesemia: Hypomagnesemia can exacerbate hyponatremia and potentiate hypokalemia, but it is not directly implicated as a cause of CPM. Magnesium disorders have distinct neurological manifestations.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes neuromuscular irritability, tetany, and seizures, but is not associated with the development of demyelinating lesions in the pons characteristic of CPM.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Central pontine myelinolysis occurs when chronic hyponatremia is corrected too rapidly, causing asymmetric reaccumulation of brain osmolytes and subsequent demyelination, particularly affecting the pons. The safest correction rate for chronic hyponatremia is less than 8-10 mEq/L in 24 hours or 18 mEq/L in 48 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibodies is incorrectl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Anti-LKM3 and Chronic Hepatitis C

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-LKM3 is associated with chronic hepatitis D, not chronic hepatitis C. In the classification of chronic hepatitis, anti-LKM3 antibodies are specifically linked to hepatitis D virus infection, while hepatitis C has different immunologic markers. This represents an important serologic distinction that helps in differentiating between these viral hepatitis types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-LKM1 and Autoimmune Hepatitis II: This association is correct. Anti-LKM1 (liver-kidney microsome type 1) antibodies are characteristic markers of type II autoimmune hepatitis. These antibodies can occasionally be found in some cases of hepatitis C, but they are primarily diagnostic for autoimmune hepatitis type II.

 

Option B. Anti-LKM2 and Drug-Induced Hepatitis: This association is correct. Anti-LKM2 antibodies are directed against cytochrome P450 enzymes and are characteristically found in cases of drug-induced hepatitis, reflecting the immunologic response to drug-metabolite adducts formed during hepatic injury.

 

Option D. Anti-SLA and Autoimmune Hepatitis Type III: This association is correct. Anti-SLA (antibodies to soluble liver antigen) are specifically associated with autoimmune hepatitis type III, which represents a serologic subcategory of autoimmune hepatitis with distinctive clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specific autoantibody profiles serve as important serologic markers that help differentiate between various forms of chronic liver disease - anti-LKM3 is specifically associated with chronic hepatitis D, not hepatitis C, while different LKM autoantibody subtypes have distinct disease associations.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B presents with right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, jaundice, and a palpable liver edge. His laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised AFP levels. Imaging reveals a hypoechoic liver lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests HCC, supported by:

 

  • Risk factor: Chronic hepatitis B
  • Clinical symptoms: RUQ pain, weight loss, jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • Lab findings: Elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Imaging: Hypoechoic lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout, classic for HCC

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: More commonly associated with PSC, liver flukes, or biliary disease

 

Option C. Focal nodular hyperplasia: Usually incidental, benign, seen in young women

 

Option D. Hepatic adenoma: More common in young women on OCPs, lacks early washout

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma presents with characteristic imaging (arterial enhancement with early washout) in a patient with chronic hepatitis B.

choices.text: Give aspirin and discharge the patient

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the past 20 minutes. The ECG demonstrates ST-segment depression, and troponin levels are positive. What is the next best step in the patient’s management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give aspirin + clopidogrel

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain radiating to the arm
  • ST-segment depression on ECG
  • Positive troponins

 

Initial management follows the MONA-B protocol, and dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is the first step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin alone and discharge: Incorrect, as NSTEMI requires hospital admission and further evaluation

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: Contraindicated in NSTEMI (only indicated for STEMI)

 

Option D. Stress test: Contraindicated in acute coronary syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSTEMI management includes dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel), and thrombolysis is contraindicated.
